title: Boaz Redeems Ruth
shortSummary: Ruth chapter 4 details Boaz’s legal redemption of Naomi’s land and Ruth, securing their family line and preserving the inheritance of Elimelech’s family. This chapter highlights God’s providential care through human faithfulness and introduces the genealogy leading to King David, underscoring God’s sovereign plan in redemption.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges

keyCharacters.name: Boaz
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy and honorable kinsman-redeemer who legally acquires Naomi’s land and marries Ruth to preserve the family line.

keyCharacters.name: Ruth
keyCharacters.description: A Moabitess widow who remains loyal to Naomi and becomes Boaz’s wife, entering the lineage of David and ultimately Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Naomi
keyCharacters.description: Widow of Elimelech who returns to Bethlehem and seeks to restore her family’s inheritance through Boaz’s redemption.

keyCharacters.name: The nearer kinsman
keyCharacters.description: A closer relative to Naomi who initially has the right to redeem the land but declines to marry Ruth, allowing Boaz to act.

definitions.definition: To buy back or reclaim property or a person, often to preserve family inheritance or provide protection, as seen in the kinsman-redeemer role.
A close relative who has the responsibility to redeem a relative’s property or marry a widow to preserve the family name and inheritance.
An ancient Israelite custom symbolizing the transfer of redemption rights or property ownership, serving as a legal confirmation.
Property or rights passed down within a family, crucial for maintaining tribal land and family legacy in Israel.

outline.heading: Boaz Meets the Nearer Kinsman
outline.description: Boaz approaches the city gate where legal transactions occur and informs the nearer kinsman about Naomi’s land and Ruth, offering him the opportunity to redeem both.

outline.heading: The Nearer Kinsman Declines Redemption
outline.description: The nearer kinsman refuses to redeem the land because it would jeopardize his own inheritance, symbolically removing his shoe to transfer the right to Boaz.

outline.heading: Boaz Redeems Naomi’s Land and Marries Ruth
outline.description: Boaz publicly declares his purchase of Elimelech’s land and his marriage to Ruth, securing the family line and receiving the community’s blessing.

outline.heading: Birth of Obed and Blessing to Naomi
outline.description: Boaz and Ruth have a son named Obed, who becomes a restorer of Naomi’s life and an ancestor of David, symbolizing God’s faithfulness and restoration.

outline.heading: Genealogy from Pharez to David
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a genealogy tracing the lineage from Pharez to David, highlighting the significance of Ruth’s place in God’s redemptive plan.

application: Trust God’s providence in difficult circumstances, knowing He works through ordinary people to accomplish His redemptive purposes.
Be faithful and loyal in relationships, as Ruth’s commitment to Naomi demonstrates the blessing of steadfast love.
Embrace God’s design for family and inheritance, honoring biblical principles of responsibility and covenant commitment.
Seek to be a person of integrity and faithfulness like Boaz, who acts justly and with generosity toward others.

keyVerses.text: And Boaz said unto the elders, and unto all the people, Ye are witnesses this day, that I have bought all that was Elimelech's, and all that was Chilion's and Mahlon's, of the hand of Naomi.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the legal and public confirmation of Boaz’s redemption, securing the family inheritance.

keyVerses.text: So Boaz took Ruth, and she was his wife: and when he went in unto her, the LORD gave her conception, and she bare a son.
keyVerses.significance: God’s blessing is evident as Ruth and Boaz’s union produces a son, continuing the Messianic lineage.

keyVerses.text: And the women said unto Naomi, Blessed be the LORD, which hath not left thee this day without a kinsman, that his name may be famous in Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse celebrates God’s faithfulness in providing a redeemer and preserving Naomi’s family line.
